title: wealth of shinty pictures uncovered in furnace
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsA treasure trove of old shinty photos has been unearthed in Furnace after lying in a suitcase for decades.The photograph collection belonged to former Furnace and Lochfyneside player, the late Niven #Bunty# Crawford, and turned up earlier this month when his daughter Christine Crawford was having a lockdown clearout.Christine#s nephew and Bunty Crawford#s grandson Scott Robertson told the Advertiser his grandfather#s story.Bunty Crawford was born and raised in Minard.Just before the Second World War he was taking a course at Glasgow University School of Art # and was in demand as a shinty player. While in the city he played for the university, and in fact played in the   Littlejohn Vase final.He joined the Royal Naval Reserve and on the outbreak of war was posted to the Royal Navy destroyer HMS Icarus. Aboard the Icarus, he saw action in the Norwegian campaign, including the the Battle of Narvik, during  and was involved in the Dunkirk evacuation.After the war Bunty ed to finish his university qualication, and married ChristinaMacCallum from Furnace in .Bunty and his young we settled in Furnace where they had three children, John, Moira and Christine. He turned out in goals for Lochfyneside shinty team, playing in the  and  Camanachd Cup finals # losing out to Newtonmore on both occasions.Lochfyneside disbanded in the s and reverted to the old Furnace club. It was at that point Bunty, a painter and decorator, stepped back from playing. He continued to follow shinty over the years often accompanied his friend, neighbour, fellow war veteran and Lochfyneside team-mate Jimmy Sinclair.Bunty was a keen photographer and recorded many matches and occasions which would otherwise have been left to the memories of the people who were there. He also captured priceless images of shinty characters now long gone but fondly remembered.He died in  at the age of .Scott himself has been a stalwart of Inveraray Shinty Club for three decades and a member of the team, along with his brother David, which lted the Camanachd Cup in .Hid grandfather would have been proud of the boys # but maybe less so about the team they were playing for. #My grandpa and Jimmy were staunch Furnace men, and there was always this Furnace Inveraray rivalry,# Scott explained.#He always said to me never to join Inveraray, and after he died, my gran carried it on.#When I was  or  I ended up playing for Inveraray, but he was dyed-in-the-wool Furnace through and through. He would be turning in his grave..!#He added: #It#s great to have these photos, and I have sent a lot of them to the Shinty Memories Facebook page, which uses memories to help folk living with issues such as dementia and isolation.#Hopefully people will enjoy seeing them.#

title: letters to the editor july 3 2020
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,Communities on the A are blighted by the noise of bikers, many with illegal exhausts.Inveraray is the gathering point for motorcyclists and on a recent Saturday during lockdown around  were gathered, not two metre social distancing, and failing to adhere to the maximum eight in a group guidance.This has become the norm throughout the summer, and it seems lockdown guidance does not apply to bikers as they have been a constant feature on the roads, even in phase one.The unofficial Argyll TT goes past our homes most weekends over the spring and summer months.I have a bike licence and understand the feeling of freedom, but three-figure speeds past residential entrances, many of them hidden, is completely unacceptable.As a resident you begin to dread the weekend and sunny days. The noise is constant and intrusive for  –  hours in a day, the decibel level in excess of  dB where sounds above  dB are harmful to hearing.This is a serious issue for residents who cannot open their doors and windows, cannot use their gardens, pets are terried, it is often impossible to have a conversation, or a phone call. The noise from hundreds of bikes is explosive and destructive.The speeds are terrying, they travel in intimidating packs, the noise is threatening and the bikers have no respect for the communities they are speeding through. They pass multiple residential entrances with limited sight lines with no care for risk. The offensive noise seems to come from two actions modying motorbike exhausts and extreme acceleration in legal bikes.If a car made a similar noise, spewed out the same polluting omissions, or did the same ridiculous speeds they would be pulled over by the police, but bikers appear above the law.As technology reduces the noise pollution of cars, planes and other forms of transport, it seems motorbikes are exempt. Bikers claim #loud pipes save lives# but is safety really the motivation for deliberately creating excessive noise Noise counts as a statutory nuisance it either unreasaonably and substantially interferes with the user or enjoyment of a home or other premises or is likely to injure health.The problem on A is known to all the statutory agencies, but nothing is done.If this is a national problem, what action needs to be taken Concerned Loch Fyne-side resident Sir,I am not qualied to judge economic competence, but considering the party he represents, I think that Councillor Redman might find it advisable to be wary of the phrase #colossal mismanagement# .For my part, I would consider a degree of incompetence to be preferable to the great damage caused over the last decade to  per cent of the UK’s people, as well as to its institutions and its reputation by the cruel, self-serving, xenophobic, elitist, dishonestregime currently in Westminster.Name supplied, LochgilpheadSir,Our charity#s support for blind and partially sighted people affected by the coronavirus lockdown has received a £, boost from the Scottish Government#s Wellbeing Fund.With this extra funding we will be able to support an additional  people and respond to the increased demand for more in-depth, one-to-one emotional support.The practical and psychological effects of losing your sight can have a signicant impact on people’s well-being, and this current situation has exacerbated the anxiety and isolation felt by many.Access to essential services such as food and medicines is more dficult as is social distancing, vital information on staying safe isn#t always in accessible formats, and many of our older members aren#t always confident about using new technology to stay in touch with others.Everyone accessing RNIB#s confidential counselling service will receive eight weekly sessions with an accredited counsellor, delivered via telephone and online, with each session normally lasting an hour.The funding will enable us to reduce the waiting list for emergency mental health sessions and also let existing clients access additional sessions.The RNIB helpline is available on   .James Adams, RNIB Scotland directorSir,Every pub across Scotland should be allowed to stock and sell beer from local independent brewers, to help them recover post-lockdown.CAMRA, the Campaign for Real Ale has launched the #Cheers for Choice# campaign.The campaign wants these arrangements to be relaxed, and MSPs are also being urged to support the Tied Pubs Bill being put forward in the Scottish Parliament by Labour MSP Neil Bibby. The legislation would give tied pub tenants protections in law, including a right to be able to sell guest beers in their pubs.Allowing small and independent brewers to sell into all pubs will also improve consumer choice and allow pub-goers to support local brewing businesses.It also makes business sense, with  per cent of pub-goers saying they would be less likely to go back to a pubit doesn’t have a range of brews from small and independent producers.Sarah Crawford, CAMRA Director for Scotland, Kirkcaldy

title: could a two way conversation transform scotlands health
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSome of us have learned in lockdown the importance of other people, and have been longing for these first personal contacts.There have been surprises in discovering just what is important in le, and the comfort of knowing you are not alone in your likes, as your favourite brand of chocolate is again sold out.We have also been made aware that the way we behave makes a dference to the future. It has taken a national emergency to get the government to acknowledge that it needs our compliance and, for that, must give us the information we need.Suddenly the choices we make are seen as vitally important, and we have a part to play in achieving success for ourselves and our community. Can this be a foundation for a future partnership that could transform the health of Scotland and the pressure on our services As a physiotherapist I became aware that there was little that one could do to impose solutions there had to be a relationship that involved two way listening, mutual trust and support to do what was necessary. In this pandemic Nicola Sturgeon has said that we have behaved in a way that saved lives and protected the NHS.When this is over we could be at the beginning of another le-altering journey.It will demand a huge sht in expectations. There is an amazing bias in society towards the idea of decrepitude and dependency in old age, when in fact encouraging dependency increases a slide into that very state. During past months many of these attitudes have been exposed and caused outrage but they are long standing and deep seated.If you have been trying to escape into fiction you might have no better idea of what is possible. Alison Flood interviewed crime writers about their work, and this is what she found.Ian Rankin is now writing about a John Rebus who has health issues, James Lee Burke has his detective Robicheaux meditating on mortality in his early s and Mark Billingham has slowed his Tom Thorne down a bit because he is in his s. Michael Connelly does not believe that it is credible to have his Harry Bosch with a badge and gun and still working for the LAPD, this in a country where the President is  and one of the presidential hopefuls .Worst of all, Sara Paretsky created a feisty, strong woman for her books, only to succumb to popular misconceptions and stop her age at  because she didn#t #want Vi to be helpless#.These fictional creations battle the evils they see in their society. Now that it is realised how our inidual decision making makes a dference, whatever our age, we have no need to feel helpless.It is time to ask for the information and support we need.

title: small but mighty navy boats deployed off west coast
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsThree of the Royal Navy’s P Archer class patrol boats have been visiting the west coast of Scotland as part of their summer deployment.The ships – HMS Biter, HMS Charger and HMS Express – support University Royal Naval Unitsand are spending a fortnight training on the west coast of Scotland.Between July  and July  the vessels will stop off at ious harbours and lochs between conducting waterborne training where they will practice maritime skills.Captain Chris Smith, naval regional commander for Scotland and Northern Ireland, said: #The Ps may be small, but they pack a punch and regularly exercise around the UK and Europe as well as supporting the fleet.#Usually we would be hosting visits from local groups and organisations, but, with the current situation, this is unfortunately not possible. We still hope to engage with local organisations across social media and using new technologies, however, andpeople spot the ships in their area please do give them a wave!#Each of the vessels is affiliated to universities around the country and has a core crew of full-time Royal Navy sailors, which in normal times would be augmented by members of the University Royal Naval Units . As this is not possible this time due to the current restrictions, each vessel will use new technologies to have a weekly virtual drill night with their associated URNU.At just over  metres long, the Ps are some of the smallest ships in the fleet and perfect for navigation and seamanship training. It also means they can access smaller harbours which, because of their size, usually can’t host Royal Navy ships.The Royal Navy has  Fast Inshore Patrol Craft which together form the First Patrol Boat Squadron.Although their primary role is to support the URNUs, two of them, HMS Tracker and HMS Raider, are permanently based at HMNB Clyde where they are part of the team safeguarding the nuclear fleet.At the same time as Biter, Charger and Express undertake their west coast deployment, four boats # Trumpeter, Archer, Explorer and Example # will sail up Scotland#s east coast.The three ships will be at Port Ellen from July  to , Oban from July  to  and Fort William from July  to . Further ports of call are planned, including Kyle of Lochalsh, Ullapool, Stornoway, Lochboisdale and Tobermory, with dates to be confirmed.PIC:Four Archer class P patrol boats together at sea. no_aNavyPatrolBoats

title: tuning into nature and getting down to business
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsIn normal circumstances busy lives and work schedules often get in the way of finding time to connect with nature, to be able to immerse oneself in the muffled sounds within a forest, seas crashing on rocky shores or the wind blowing the lonesome notes of a curlew across the moor.When did you last hear the bark of deer, watch an otter hunting for fish to take to its young or spot the smooth glide of a golden eagle overhead  Have you noticed how tree branches reach to the sunlight or bend to the wind and did you know you can use such traits to help navigate  Have you gazed at the starlit skies on a clear night and been able to name the constellations or point to the North Star  Have you ever foraged for wild ingredients and flowers to create a new culinary delight For many the tragedy of a world in the throes of a pandemic has brought around a very dferent pause, allowing time to tune once more into nature, evensuch a pause is brief. Perhaps for the first time in their lives they have heard the bark of deer or spotted something in nature that is totally new to them. And many will have seen footage of the animals and creatures that tentatively stepped into urban settings whilst humankind remained under lockdown.But that is changing as we ease back into a new normality.Economics and peoples’ livelihoods are, of course, firmly entwined with modern day living, human survival and wellbeing it is extremely important that we find a route to recovery and many are suffering deeply. But what we do not want to do is fall back into the same old traps that were so detrimental to the wildle, nature and ecosystems of our planet. Finding a way forward and a new balance is not just crucial for other species but for that of our own children and future generations too.Many will have been shocked at the sudden increase in fly tipping during lockdown plus the thoughtless parking and abandonment of picnic rubbish, disposable barbecues and indiscriminate toileting as lockdown eased. All have grave consequences for wildle and nature.The result is the burning, choking, strangling, trapping or poisoning of animals, birds, plants and aquatic le.Taking care of our surroundings and appreciating nature is a real joy. Teaching children the beauty of the outdoors and how to care for it can bring a lelong love for natureyou love something you usually wish to protect it.And learning never stops for any of us. Sometimes it is the basics that are needed before we move on to the complexities of natural navigation or learning our stars.So for this month here is one tip : learn how to go to the toilet in the outdoors!Doing this responsibly and teaching your children makes for a lelong enjoyment of walking and exploring without the bane of wondering where the next toilet is. I know many people who find it incredibly dficult, not great when in the middle of nowhere miles from home.In a nutshell the key is to carry out all paper and sanitary waste in a sealable bag, to go aMountaineering Scotland has excellent online guidance on how to dispose of your natural waste.I hope, like me, you will wish to continue to enjoy nature and take the time to care for and immerse your senses in this beautul world we live in.

title: borders-golfers-allowed-play-says-msp
story: BORDERS golfers and anglers should be allowed toto action, according to Rachael Hamilton.The Conservative MSP says she has written to the Scottish Government in a bid to get restrictions lted on outdoor activities.Mrs Hamilton said shooting and angling are among the activities which make an "immense contribution" to the rural economy.She said: "Outdoor sports, such as golfing, hiking and fishing, could take place with the necessary social distancing measures and it would not jeopardise the governmentrsquos efforts in tackling this pandemic."Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced last week that residents in England canto certain outdoor pursuits, including tennis and golf.But the Scottish Government has decided to retain the stay at home message, while now allowing people to exercise more than once a day.Mrs Hamilton, who represents Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire, says she has written to the Scottish cabinet secretary for rural economy and tourism, Fergus EwingMrs Hamilton, the shadow secretary, said: "We currently have an extraordinary situation in my constituency, around Coldstream, where people can happily fish in the English half of the River Tweed, whilst anglers in Scotland can only watch on from the Scottish side, where fishing is still not permitted at this time."By their nature, outdoor-based sports see participants spread out, whether over a hillside, across an open space or along a river."In the Borders and across rural Scotland, the angling and shooting industry needs to have clarity so it can plan for the new season."I urge the Scottish Government to rethink its restrictions, given the nature of these sports, and the immense contribution they make to our rural economy."

title: selkirk-rugby-players-bid-clean-town
story: HAVING just completed a sponsored charity project that raised almost pound, in under a fortnight for the townrsquos foodbank, Selkirk Rugby Clubrsquos players arenrsquot letting the grass grow under their feet.This week members of the clubrsquos playing squad have embarked on yet another lsquochallengersquo to support the local community ndash litter collection.The idea came from former st XV skipper Ross Nixon, and comes in the wake of a similar venture undertaken by Glasgow Warriorsrsquo professional players.ldquoWhen yoursquore walking in and around Selkirk, you canrsquot help noticing pieces of litter that have been left lying around, often when proper bins arenrsquot that far away, said Nixon.ldquoI thought it would be a good idea for Selkirk players to take a bin bag with them when they head out to take their daily exercise, picking up any litter they see next to paths or along roadside verges.ldquoWersquore lucky in Selkirk to have such unspoilt countryside to McColm, Ewan MacDougall and Liam Cassidy ndash to collect litter on their walks.ldquoEach of this trio will then challenge a further three players to collect litter, and in turn these three will title: film-fans-enjoy-upgraded-galashiels-cinema
story: FILM fans in the Borders will soon enjoy an improved cinema in Galashiels.The Pavilion Cinema, on Market Street, is upgrading its sound system after receiving a pound, grant towards the cost of work.Pavilion manager Andrew Poole said: ldquoWe canrsquot wait to hear the dference this makes to the sound quality in all four screens and wersquore extremely excited to be able to share that with our customers when we do reopen.The cinema secured cash from The National Lottery through Screen Scotlandrsquos Cinema Equipment Fund.High-quality equipment is being installed, some of which will help customers who are visually impaired or hearing impaired.Mr Poole said: ldquoWersquore extremely grateful to Screen Scotland for this funding which will enable us to transform our audio provision for all our customers.ldquoIn the current economic climate, we wouldnt have been able to embark on such an ambitious project without this vital support.ldquoFilm is an immersive experience and a filmrsquos soundtrack is  per cent of that experience.ldquoItrsquos vital that we continue to offer our customers the very best experience we possibly can.ldquoThe current sound system in the Pavilion does a good job, but it couldnrsquot be described as cutting edge.Screen Scotlandrsquos Jenner Armitage said: ldquoWhen we launched the Cinema Equipment Fund last year, we had no idea what  was going to bring, but investing in the resilience of Scotlandrsquos film exhibition sector is more important than ever.ldquoWhen Scotlandrsquos cinemas reopen, they will be able to offer high-quality experiences, with ied programmes, and within local communities.Mr Poole says the developments will include the following upgrades:Replacing all sound processors with Dolby CP Cinema Sound Processors enabling Dolby . sound in all four screensReplacing all ampliers with QSC DPA Cinema AmpliersReplacing all speakers with QSC Cinema SpeakersInstallation of a Dolby Fidelio system in all four screens

title: dismissed-workers-accuse-borders-branch-unfair-treatment
story: A BUSINESS faces an employment tribunal following allegations by former workers.TheBorder reported last week that LeHeal, which sells body and mind treatments, would be closing its clinics in Peebles and Linlithgow.Business partners Sam Hastings and Erica Douglas said the mounting pressures of government regulations and costs of personal protective equipmentmade it impossible for them to reopen their high street branches.The owners said six staff members were employed at the Peebles branch, adding that the workerswould be supported ldquopractically and emotionally.However, some of the former workerssay they were dumbfounded after reading LeHeals statement. They are claimingthey were unfairly treated by their ex-bosses.One former staff member gave a long list of allegations, adding: ldquoTo read what was being said by them [LeHeal] on Facebook, it felt like a slap in the face.The former workersare now taking their ex-bosses to an employment tribunal which will take place at a hearing in Glasgow on Wednesday, July .LeHeal co-owner Ms Hastings said: ldquoWe have answered a request by the court to explain our decision-making throughout this crisis and we are confident wersquoll be found to have acted as best we could amid the chaos.

title: face-coverings-mandatory-scotlands-shops---rules-exempt
story: FACE coverings will become mandatory in Scotlands shops from the end of next week, the First Minister has confirmed.During her daily briefing, Nicola Sturgeon said the Scottish Government has been considering the issue of face coverings "for some time now".She confirmed it will become mandatory in Phase .Why the change Face coverings became mandatory in Scotland on all public transport on June .The First Minister said: "As we all start to interact more, it is vital that we take all reasonable steps to reduce risk."And we know that these coveringscan help reduce the risk of transmission indoors."She added: "This is a really important wayfor all of us to help protect each other and to display that sense of solidarity that has served us well."When does it become mandatory Ms Sturgeon said the enforcement will take place on Phase  - July .However sheurged Scots not to wait until next week, asking them to get into the habit now.How will it be enforced The First Minister said the rules will be enforced in a similar way to those on public transport.She said it would be "not fair or reasonable" to expect shop workers to enforce the rules - and instead it would be down to the police to do so.Fixed penalty notices - which start at pound - could be handed out by the police, but she says they will do so only asa last resort.Ms Sturgeon added: "All of us can help by doing this voluntarily because it can make a dference".Who is exempt Children under five will be exempt from this rule, Ms Sturgeon confirmed, along with those with certain medical conditions.Following in line with the public transport rules, then the following groups may also be exempt:Police officers first responders in an emergencyStaff separate by a physical barrier ndash including bus drivers behind a screenAnyone with ahealthcondition where a mask would cause dficulty, including asthmaYou need to take medicationTo speak with someone who lip readsWhen asked to remove it by a relevant authority, e.g. Police officer.But Ms Sturgeonsaid: ldquoFor everyone , face coverings will be mandatory."What  was announced MsSturgeon also announced that the two-metre social distancing rule can be reduced in the hospitality and retail sectors and on public transport at that time.Pubs, restaurants and shops will be allowed to adhere to a one-metre rule instead, with mitigation measures in place.But the general rule in law will be that businesses must take reasonable measures to ensure two-metre distancing is maintained, she said.The First Minister also said , patients have now died in Scotland after testing positive for coronavirus, up by one from , on Wednesday.A total of , people have tested positive for the virus, up by five from , the previous day.

title: volvo-recalls-170-000-cars-seatbelt-fault---full-list
story: Car manufacturer Volvo has urgently recalled more than , of its vehicles after uncovering a rare safety issue.Volvo Cars investigations have founda problem relating to the front seat belt fastening, mounted on the outer side of the front seat.The front seat belt fastening cable may over time suffer from reduced strength under certain circumstances.Which modelsare affected Models affected are previous-generation S, S Cross Country, V, V Cross Country, XC, V, XC and S cars produced between  and .No currently produced cars are affected.Are the authorities aware of this issue Yes -Volvo says its UK company is working closely with the DVSAin relation to the matter.Is my car safe to use  What should I doI am concerned about my seatbelt A statement on Volvos website reads: "Please be assured that this issue is extremely rare: we have no reports of any related incidents, and the issue can only occur over time and with a specic set of circumstances."Until your vehicle has entering the seat."This will prevent any damage to the cable."Who can motorists get in touch withthey have concerns To speak to someone about the issue,call Volvos dedicated team on  .

title: air-bridges-apply-scotland-can-go-holiday-abroad
story: HOLIDAYMAKERS from England can embark on overseas trips from next Friday as quarantine restrictions are lted ndash but not people from Scotland.The current -day isolation policy for peopleto or visiting Scotland remains in place for now, the Scottish Government has confirmed, despite the restrictions being eased south of the border.As it stands, people from England will be able to travel to destinations such as Spain, France, Italy and Germany.A full list of countries which the UK Government regards as posing aldquoreduced risk of Covid- will be published later today, and could feature as many as  nations.However, there is still a chance that travellers from the UK will have to self-isolate on arrival into some of the other states.The blanket guide against all but essential travel will also be changed tomorrow.What is an air bridge An air bridge, also known as a travel corridor, will allow tourists to travel between two countries without the need to quarantine.The agreements between countries, particularly those with low cases ofcoronavirus, allow two-way travel without restrictions.Do air bridges apply to Scotland The First Minister has criticised the UK Government for failing to consult the devolved administration before announcing the proposed changes.The Scottish Government says a four-nations agreement hasnot yet been reached.A spokesman said the UK Government is lting quarantine restrictions for countries ldquowhich present dfering levels of risk.ldquoIt is disappointing that the UK Government have chosen to make an announcement on the countries they intend to exempt before a four nations agreement has been reached, he said.ldquoWe would still like to reach a four nations approachpossible, but that is dficult when the UK Government change proposals and give us last-minute sight of them.While border controls remains a reserved matter, the issue of health is devolved ndash therefore allowing the Scottish Government to retain control over quarantine measures in this country.This means, as it stands, the current restrictions remain in place in Scotland for now.Could this change Speaking on Monday, the First Minister said she wanted to ldquotake a bit of time to consider the public health impact of removing the -day quarantine.She added she wanted to look at the evidence underpinning the decision south of the border and would feed back as soon as possible.What are the quarantine rules in Scotland The following measures were put in place from June :Residents and visitors arriving from abroad must self-isolate for  daysAll travellers must complete an online passenger locator form supplying contact details, travel details and the address of where they will self-isolateBorder Force will carry out spot checks at the border and can impose a fine of pound on those who refuse to comply.Arrangements will be made for those arriving into Scotland to be contacted during self-isolation to receive public health advice and informationThose who fail to self-isolate can be fined pound.Persistent offenders can be reported to the procurator fiscal for potential prosecution and a maximum pound, fine.

story: BORDERS revellers have snapped up every ticket for a ldquobeer garden event at Hawick rugby clubrsquos ground.The club plans to host drinkers on the Mansfield Park pitch at a series of events, starting on July .Talks with Scottish Borders Counciland the police are continuing today .A joint statement from the club and SBC reads: ldquoBoth the club and the council are hopeful that the planned event on Saturday, July , which has already been fully booked, will be able to take place, subject to all public health matters being resolved and the necessary licence being approved.Beer gardens in Scotland are allowed to open from Mondayas lockdown restrictions continue to be eased.This is the full statement issued on Thursday, July "Hawick Rugby Football Club and Scottish Borders Council would like to confirm that they continue to work together with a view to the club holding lsquobeer gardenrsquo events on the pitch."The club requires an occasional licence for these events to take place and has submitted an application today to Scottish Borders Council."A Safety Advisory Group meeting involving the club, Council and other relevant partners, including Police Scotland, will take place tomorrow to enable detailed discussions to take place on all necessary matters, including public health."In light of this, the club is reviewing its plans for events currently scheduled for the early part of next week."Both the club and the Council are hopeful that the planned event on Saturday  July, which has already been fully booked, will be able to take place, subject to all public health matters being resolved and the necessary licence being approved."

title: borders-book-festival-2020-line-up-revealed-july-talks
story: AN online version of the Borders Book Festival begins this month.Festival co-director Paula Ogilvie says ldquothe skyrsquos the limit for the series of talks, which kick off on July  and run every Sunday for  weeks.Stalwarts, including Rory Bremner and James Naughtie, will be back to entertain fans in the pre-recorded sessions.But they will also be joined by new names including YouTube chef Suzanne Mulholland ndash aka The Batch Lady ndash and childrenrsquos author Chris Lloyd.After each talk plays out live, authors will be available to answer questions at the end.The series has been organised because of the cancellation of the physical festival, which had been due to be held in June at Harmony House, Melrose.ldquoWe thought it was quite an important thing to do, said Mrs Ogilvie, on the idea of a virtual version.ldquoItrsquos not a perfect experience and we canrsquot replicate the real event, but at least the author is still there and still interacting with the audience.While audiences wonrsquot be sitting ldquoshoulder to shoulder and seeing the whites of the authorsrsquo eyes, it does mean more people will be able to join the festival, albeit virtually.Mrs Ogilvie said: ldquoWersquove got festival goers who now live in far flung places."We had a bit of response with people saying, lsquoI live in Canada now, I was really missing the festival but I can be part of it ndash I can watch it.rsquo So therersquos a good up side to it.The festival will also be able to talk to authors on the other side of the world.ldquoFor the August programme, wersquove got some names that are not based in the UK, said Mrs Ogilvie.ldquoThis allows us to have authors and thinkers who ordinarily wersquod have a bit of a challenge to get to the UK, never mind the Scottish Borders.But launch day will see one guest who is always happy toto the Borders ndash festival favourite Rory Bremner, in conversation with festival founder Alistair Moffat.ldquoRory Bremner is a real stalwart of the festival, said Mrs Ogilvie.ldquoHersquos been with us since , he appears every year and has also helped us to shape the programme.ldquoHersquoll do what Rory does ndash therersquoll be impersonations, and a lot of chat about the last  or so years that hersquos been involved in the festival and the highlights from that, so thatrsquoll be fun.Also appearing on July , in the pm slot, is internet sensation Suzanne Mulholland, aka The Batch Lady.The Batch Lady, whose book of the same name is out now, has garnered , followers on her YouTube, Instagram and Facebook channels. She has also appeared in Hellomagazine, the Daily Mailand The Sun.ldquoShersquos quite a phenomenon, said Mrs Ogilvie. ldquoShersquos already super popular but is gathering more momentum and I love the fact shersquos based in the Scottish Borders.,params: .pushldquoFor her event with us shersquoll talk about her book, but also do a -minute demonstration with a number of dferent recipes from the book.Other highlights of the July programme include journalist and broadcaster Kirsty Wark in conversation with former Vogueeditor Alexandra Shulman, and an evening with award-winning crime writers Mark Billingham and Chris Brookmyre.Moving the -year-old book festival online might have been a ldquosteep learning curve, according to Mrs Ogilvie, but it has also been essential to keep the event alive, and books and authors in the limelight.ldquoIt just means we can start to shine even more of a light on the Scottish Borders and our authors and what the festival does, said Mrs Ogilvie. ldquoThe skyrsquos the limit.Borders Book Festivals July programmeJuly am: Make Your Own Rockpool Book with Jill Calderpm: The Batch Ladypm: Rory Bremner in conversation with Alistair MoffatJuly am: Joseph Coelho  Fiona Lumbers: Luna Loves Artpm: Alexandra Shulman in conversation with Kirsty Warkpm: James NaughtieJuly am: Humanimal ndash Incredible Ways Animals are Just Like Us! with Chris Lloydpm: Paul Murton in conversation with Alistair Moffatpm: Mark Billingham in conversation with Chris BrookmyreAuthor names for August and September will be released at a later date.For more information, go to the Borders Book Festival website.

title: face-masks-buy-face-coverings-independent-stores-scotland
story: Face coverings are to become mandatory in Scotlands shops from July , First Minister Nicola Sturgeon has announced.The new rule comes just two weeks after passengers on public transport were told they must cover their faces when travelling.Some Scots across the country have already been practising the habit of wearing face masks when out in public, but as covering up becomes a legal requirement, many of us are now in the market for a quality face mask.Of course, major fashion brands such as ASOS, Boohoo and River Island were quick to get in on the action and are selling masks online.Butindependent and Scottish-made masks are more your style, here is our rundown of where in Scotland is selling the worldrsquos latest hot commodity.BroraWith Scottish cashmere at its heart, luxury clothing brand Brora began producing face masks for both adults and children from the surplus material at one of their Portuguese factories making PPE.Edinburgh store manager Sophie Hopkinson said: ldquoWe really wanted to come up with a great idea to give back, so pound from every mask will go to NHS charities and other small charities.ldquoThey are really nice to wear since theyrsquore a natural fibre, and ever since we opened theyrsquove been incredibly popular."Breathe EasyWhen the pandemic hit, engineer and entrepreneur Gavin McAdam got to work creating masks.His Edinburgh-based start-up Breathe Easy began by asking only for donations to try and help the third-party care sector and vulnerable groups get access to quality medical-grade face masks.And when someone got in touch askingMr McAdam could create a face mask for their deaf son, the company set about creating and trialling a cotton face mask with a transparent plastic face .Now Breathe Easy continues to issue free face masks to a iety of charities around Scotland, but also sells both full cotton masks and those with transparent  for deaf and hard of hearing communities on their website.Owner Gavin McAdam said: ldquoWersquore growing all the time and employing more people to keep up with demand.ldquoWersquore also working in partnership with the National Manufacturing Institute and Glasgow University in the development of a novel material that has natural microbial properties, engineered to capture the exact particle size of the Covid- virus."We will be trialling the first of these masks in two or three weeks."Slanj KiltsSlanj Kilts recently came into the limelight when Nicola Sturgeon was seen wearing one of their latest wares.The First Minister was spotted modelling the homeless tartan design, which sees % of all its sales donated to Shelter.General Manager Ross Lyall said: ldquoWe started making face masks in February in anticipation of lockdown. Sales were trickling through, but then of course Nicola wore our mask, and it went mental.ldquoThe traditional kilt business is dependent on the wedding industry, so we were very worried about the way things are at the moment and asking ourselves where the money is going to come fromthere are no weddings.ldquoSuddenly we had thousands of orders going through, so we are currently trying to recruit as many sowers as possible to keep up with demand.Mischke LingerieAs an Aberdeen-based brand known for its lingerie, this company is now also producing cloth masks in a iety of dferent colours and prints, with a pocket for a filter, for only pound..Designer Hazel Lethaby, founder of Mischke Lingerie said:"We have a passion for making small and beautul things and firmly believe that the Devil is in the detail."I started making masks as I saw a need to use my skills to produce something for the general public so that there was no need for people to buy up supplies of medical grade equipment."The masks I make are not designed as PPE but can be worn to comply with the guidelines in stores and on public transport."I am using mainly % cotton gingham as it has a stylish and playful look and its easy to wash, making the masks more sustainable. The design is also zero waste, there are no offcuts!"Mirka Bridal CoutureOwner of this Kirkcaldybridal store Mirka Jankowska has been hard at workcollaboratingwith Laila Letteringto produce limited edition face masks during lockdown.,params: .pushFor each face mask purchase Mirka Bridal Couture are donatinga face mask to the Childrenrsquos Oncology Ward in Edinburgh who are in need of reusable face masks for their young patients and their families.Julie Macintyre Handmade Bags Julie Macintyre, from Dalkeithnear Edinburgh,has pressed pause on making bags to create beautul Harris Tweed face masks.After trialling several designsshe found that the above product, with % cotton lining, was most comfortable to wear.Handmade by DotThis independent store has added face masks to its list of handmade items, which already includes bottle light lamps, hand-knitted items, handmade cards, and jewellery.The face masks come in a wide range of colours and patterns, are washable and double lined with a filter pocket.

title: tescos-major-changes-shopping-online
story: Tesco has confirmed a big change for people who regularly shop online and use their home delivery service.The retailer saysa feature that was previously suspended - due to coronavirus - has now ed.What is the change for online shoppers Tescos Delivery Saver plan - which stopped back in April - resumed on Wednesday, July .The supermarket giant says themove will make it easier for their most loyal customers to easily picka delivery slot.In an email to shoppers, Tesco said: "As you know, we suspended Delivery Saver payments in April, which allowed us to support , vulnerable customers with .million orders."We couldnt have done this without your patience and understanding."Wersquore now planning to restart Delivery Saver plans from  July."What  has changed Tesco has also updated themaximum item restriction for deliveries.When lockdown began in March, orders were limited to a maximum item number of .Now, the limit has been increased to amaximum of  items.What is theTesco Delivery Saver plan Delivery Saver is Tescos subscription-based delivery service, which is designed to help shoppers reduce the cost of home deliveries for their grocery orders.The plans come with a iety of benefits, according to Tesco.These include:Free delivery onshopping across all of Tescos online departments.If shoppers spend more on a plan than they would have done on deliveries, the retailer will email them an eCouponwith the dference -within  days of their plan ending.Customers will also earn points on every Delivery Saver payment, as well as collecting points on their shopping.Online shoppers will also be able to getearly access for delivery slots at Christmas and Easter.

title: borders-trader-a-true-champion-local-businesses
story: A BORDERS businessman has been hailed as a high street legend for promoting fellow traders in his town.Shop owners and locals have heaped praise on Ian McFadyen for his community spirit, calling him ldquoan ambassador for Peebles.Ian, who owns the House of Gaia with his we Paula, often closes the doors to his High Street shop to operate a live video feed.Streaming through his social media page, he gives details on every business in the town and tells his audience what they have to offer.Cafeacute owners Della Murray and Artur Budenko told the Border : ldquoIan is a real advocate for the High Street and surrounding areas."A true champion of local businesses. Full credit must be given to him for all that he does for us.Ian and Paula are the proprietors of a mind body and spirit shop, which boasts one of the largest selections of crystals in Scotland.The couple recently helped NHS hospitals create chill-out zones for stressed medical staff fighting the coronavirus.They donated goods to the Borders General Hospital, Edinburgh Royal Infirmary, and Hay Lodge Community Hospital.Their High Street shop is now back open and we caught up with Ian to ask how the first day went.ldquoIt was fantastic ndash we had a full shop throughout most of the day, he said."We had people posting on Facebook saying that they wanted to come to the shop."A family who lived in Peebles, and have now moved to Edinburgh, came down specically for the shop opening ndash which was great.ldquoPeople have been super respectful of each other, social distancing and staying safe."There is a massive dference in the High Street and the atmosphere as the connections are being made again.ldquoAs a community wersquore a community of shopkeepers as well. When we see services like Coltmanrsquos Restaurant close and then reopen again, itrsquos fantastic."Nobody is going to come to Peebles for one shop ndash we need dferent services.ldquoIrsquom new to retail and I had no idea how dficult it would be. The glory days of retail on the High Street are gone so itrsquos very hand to mouth with people.ldquoWhen I see people opening their doors, or not able to open their doors, or struggling to purchase new stock or new lines, I feel that."I feel exactly what every other shopkeeper or business has in the High Street.A humble man, Ian is quick to praise other businesses for their efforts through the lockdown.ldquoI look at shops like Scott Brothers which has been servicing the community for years."Irsquove been in Peebles on and off for  years and since the day I first came here that shop has been open."Theyrsquove had to deal with massive changes in retail, like big multinationals like BQ and Screwfix coming in and really affecting their business."Yet throughout the lockdown they were open and servicing their local community and that needs to be recognised.True to form, the day after reopening, Ian popped a lsquoBack in  minutes sign on his shop door.He proceeded along the High Street giving a shout-out to his neighbouring retailers and businesses in a live vlog, to which one viewer wrote: ldquoYoursquore a Peebles legend.

title: support-scottish-independence-jumped-says-poll
story: SUPPORT for Scottish independence has risen markedly, according to a new poll.A Panelbase poll for The Sunday Timesfound that  per cent backed the lsquoyesrsquo side.The result reflects a five-point rise in support for independence since the last such poll in March, alongside a five-point fall for the unionist side.The poll of , voters in Scotland was conducted between Tuesday and Friday.According to The Sunday Times, politics professor John Curtice believes First Minister Nicola Sturgeonrsquos handling of the coronavirus pandemic has helped to boostthe cause of independence.He said: ldquoNever before have the foundations of public support for the union looked so weak.ldquoUnsurprisingly, for many nationalists, the past three months have exemplied how Scotland could govern itself better as an independent, small country.ldquoMore importantly, it may have persuaded some former unionists of that claim, too.

title: sam-heughan-scottish-actor-tipped-fans-next-james-bond
story: SCOTTISH actor Sam Heughan has been tipped by James Bond fans to take over the role as .Outlander actor Heughan, , beat off stars including Idris Elba and Tom Hardy in a poll forRadioTimes.The poll attracted almost , votes from across the world, with the Dumfries and Galloway-born actor coming away the clear favourite - with almost % of the votes.Sam HeughanThe current , Daniel Craig, has insisted No Time To Die - which will be released later this year after being delayed by the coronavirus - will be his last turn as Bond.Heughanpreviously revealed he auditioned for the role of Bond  years ago for Casino Royale."I think a lot of actors were seen in the UK," he told This Morning. title: first-pint-english-pubs-reopened
story: Border reporter Callum Hodgson has been staying in his native north-east during lockdown. On Saturday, he went out for a pint to mark the reopening of Englands pubs...I DONrsquoT think I have ever been in two minds about going to the pub.And I never thought I would ever have to write a piece explaining what it is like to go for a drink in one.But lockdown has made people anxious.So, as I have been working in England for the past three months, we thought you might like to know what measures pubs are taking south of the border ndash as Scotland prepares to reopen.I thought it would be best to pick one I know well ndash my lsquolocalrsquo, the one I have frequented since legally allowed to do so.But this time it was a stranger experience.This time I actually had to book in advance to make sure I could get in on lsquoSuper Saturdayrsquo.And on arrival punters were told to use hand sanitiser gel, which was provided.At the door I was greeted by the lsquohostrsquo who showed me to my allocated seat.You were not able to move to another area and the only need to stand up was to go to the bar or to the toilet.A sheet of paper was given so you could write down your name and contact details ndash just in case you need to be traced in the future. That can make you feel slightly uneasy.Perspex screens have been installed at the counter and several urinals and toilet stalls were marked out of order.And there was no entertainment ndash no jukebox, no pool table and no darts.The pubrsquos  tables were placed at least two metres apart ndash so there was no need to come into contact with anybody .When buying a drink, you had to follow a one-way system around the bar and there was a contactless card machine although you could still use cash.Overall, I would say the pub I visited took all the necessary steps to make it as safe as possible.There was no overcrowding and everyone stuck to the rules until closing time ndash which was at pm.Would I visit again  Yes. My namersquos in the book for the same table at the same time next week.I am sure there will be places which are not as organised as mypub.But my experience was a dferent, but positive one.I may, however, take a dferent viewI receive a phone call.

title: beautiful-national-trust-scotland-tourist-spots-reopening-today
story: DAY-TRIPPERS across Scotland can rejoice as dozens of tourist hotspots reopen for the first time since lockdown.The National Trust for Scotland has announced outdoor sites across the country will be able to welcome visitors as of today.It comes following changes to lockdown measures from the Scottish Government, which allows people to travel further than five miles for leisure - with exceptions in place in parts of Dumfries and Galloway.Of the sites opening today, two will only open with timed entry to manage numbers and maintain safe physical distancing ndash Culzean Country Park in Ayrshire and Threave Garden in Dumfries and Galloway.More than , slots have already been pre-booked in the first few days of Culzean tickets being made available online.It comes after the charity said some indoor facilities may not reopen until the   season including Bannockburn Visitor Centre, Hill of Tarvit, House of the Binns, Kippen Smiddy, Leith Hall, Holmwood and Souter Johnniersquos Gallowayndash Threave .Edinburgh and Lothiansndash Inveresk Lodge GardenMalleny Garden.Fendash Culross PalaceFalkland PalaceKellie Castle .Glasgowndash Greenbank Garden .Highlandsndash Brodie Castle,
